awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Examining Compliance with Rights Regimes
awd_abstract_narration:
Title: Collaborative Research: Examining Compliance with Rights Regimes

Abstract: 
The protection of human rights, including women's rights, is a cornerstone of economic development, social progress, and the promotion of peace around the globe. While numerous international institutions seek to protect women's rights, it remains unclear if, when, and how these institutions can effectively safeguard women?s rights. Understanding the processes by which political leaders and citizens mobilize around international women's rights laws and institutions is critical for improving the efficacy of these institutions. Accordingly, this project will focus on state compliance with international human rights rulings and recommendations on women's rights issues.

This project will examine the rulings and recommendations of the European Court of Human Rights, the UN Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women, and the UN Universal Periodic Review that are handed down to European states on issues of women's rights. As well, the research will draw on interviews and case studies in Denmark, The Netherlands, Norway, and Spain, each of which has strong democratic institutions but varying levels of compliance with international women's rights institutions' recommendations. The project will create and disseminate a new dataset on women's rights recommendations, the Women's Rights Recommendation Digital Database, which will be used for a battery of statistical tests to identify the factors that affect compliance with international women?s rights recommendations. The database, statistical analyses, interviews, and case studies will provide insight into the macro-level factors that impact the effectiveness of women's rights institutions and the processes behind compliance with international women's rights recommendations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project generated new data and theoretical frameworks to understand the conditions under which countries comply with international human rights recommendations, specifically with respect to women?s rights. International human rights institutions use recommendations to improve countries? human rights practices and policies. These recommendations are plentiful, with countries receiving tens if not hundreds of human rights recommendations each year. Despite the importance of these recommendations to the international human rights system, relatively little scholarship has evaluated compliance at the recommendation level, relying instead on annual country-level human rights data to assess compliance with international law.

The cornerstone to this project has been the creation of two new datasets: the Women?s Rights Recommendations Digital Database and the Women?s Rights Compliance Database. These two datasets provide nuanced data on the features of individual women?s rights recommendations as well as various steps in the compliance process for individual recommendations, allowing scholars to better understand the conditions under which countries comply with international law?and when they do not.  

These data open new doors for understanding the dynamics of international human rights law. While previous research has been limited to a focus on country-level analyses, the new datasets created through this project allow scholars and stakeholders to take a more nuanced look, considering, for example, how the quality of the recommendations and the types of required actions facilitate compliance. Using these new datasets, scholars, activists, and stakeholders are able to examine the ways in which compliance varies within countries, that is, the factors that explain why a single country chooses to comply with some recommendations and not others. Additionally, these original datasets also allow users to draw comparisons across the quality of and compliance with multiple international human rights institutions? recommendations, including recommendations made by the United Nations? Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women, by states through the United Nations? Universal Periodic Review mechanism, and by the Committee of Ministers of the European Court of Human Rights.

In addition to the empirical contributions, this project introduces a novel theoretical framework for understanding compliance. It reconceptualizes compliance as a process, rather than an outcome, and generates a typology of the compliance process. This theoretical framework also opens new avenues for research. By moving beyond a simple dichotomy of compliance/non-compliance, this project allows scholars and stakeholders alike to better understand which practices and interventions can improve compliance and human rights law throughout the recommendation process.

Scholars, policymakers, activists, and students can engage with this research in a variety of ways, including through our published research and our website and data visualization tool, the Women?s Rights Recommendations and Compliance Explorer (WRCCE.org). This website and data visualization tool can be easily customizable for a wide range of users, including the general public. 

By improving our collective understanding of compliance with international human rights law, this project not only advances the relevant academic literature but also provides policy-relevant and actionable information about how to best protect human rights.
